TEXT.English: Health Spa
Often found at natural springs Health Spas are places for taking the waters and hopefully getting healthy. they have existed since antuquity.
TEXT.Polish: Uzdrowisko - miejscowość dysponująca naturalnymi czynnikami leczniczymi, do których zalicza się wody mineralne oraz właściwości klimatyczne. Warunkiem powstania miejscowości uzdrowiskowej jest występowanie walorów przyrodniczych. Wody mineralne służą do kąpieli leczniczych i do kuracji pitnej, a właściwości klimatyczne stosowane są wklimatoterapii.

TEXT.English: An Health Spa provides a health boost to the city it is built in plus provides some protection against disease.
Universal Health Care

Universal health care is a socialist government system that seeks to provide health care access and coverage to all members of society. It is implemented through legislation, regulation and increased taxation (Redistribution of Wealth).
TEXT.Polish: Opieka zdrowotna - ogół środków mających na celu zapobieganie i leczenie chorób. Realizowana jest za pomocą systemu opieki zdrowotnej.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Universal Health Care[COLOR_REVERT] National Wonder increases the population in every city by 1.
TEXT.French: La [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Couverture Santé Universelle[COLOR_REVERT] est une Merveille Nationale qui augment d'1 la population de chaque Ville.

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET][COLOR_YELLOW]HELP: [COLOR_REVERT]All cities receive a one time +1 Population increase.
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Chaque ville reçoit un bonus de +1 en Population.
TEXT.Polish: [ICON_BULLET]Populacja we wszystkich miastach jednorazowo zwiększa się o 1.

TEXT.English: Persian Cusine Supply Store
Wise Woman

As gatherers explored their surroundings and what the results of consuming various native substances they began to learn what would make a person sick, what would provide sustenance, and what would assist in alleviating various symptoms of disease, injury and discomfort. The wise women who had spent their younger years gathering, keeping and sharing verbal records of what was beneficial for various purposes would often be turned to by the tribe as a source of healing and guidance. This role grew in significance as the human mind evolved into more and more advanced forms deepening the capacity for knowledge retention and application.

Use the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Wise Woman[COLOR_REVERT] to heal units, develop early healing experience awards, and aid in keeping disease under control in your earliest cities. They are extremely useful, but expensive to produce and maintain. Additionally, Wise Women require Wild Herbs in the city in which they are built. The Wise Woman can be upgraded to an [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Healer[COLOR_REVERT], after discovering Naturopathy.
TEXT.French: Utilisez les [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Vieilles femmes[COLOR_REVERT] pour soigner vos unités, développer de l'expérience en soin, et garder sous contrôle la prolifération de maladies dans vos villes primitives. Elles sont extrêmement utiles, mais cher à produire et entretenir. De plus, il est nécessaire d'avoir une parcelle d'herbes sauvages pour pouvoir recruter une vieille femme. Après la découverte de la Naturopathie, elles peuvent être améliorées en [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Guérisseurs[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: Healer
The Healer provides his patients with medicinal herbs, which were very effective in healing the allergies, and raising and renewing the body vitality.

Use the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Healer[COLOR_REVERT] to heal troops. They are fast moving, but expensive to produce and maintain. Additionally, Healers require the Healer's Hut in the city in which they are built. The Healer can be upgraded to an [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Apothecary[COLOR_REVERT], after discovering Education.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Guérisseur[COLOR_REVERT] permet de guérir les troupes. Ils se déplacent rapidement, mais sont coûteux à produire et à entretenir. En outre, les guérisseurs ont besoin d'une cabane de Guérisseur dans la ville dans laquelle ils sont construits. Le guérisseur peut être amélioré en [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT] Apothicaire [COLOR_REVERT], après avoir découvert l'éducation.

TEXT.English: Apothecary
The Apothecary provides his patients with medicinal herbs, which were very effective in healing the allergies, and raising and renewing the body vitality.
TEXT.French: L'Apothicaire fournit à ses patients des plantes médicinales, très efficaces pour la guérison des allergies, et permettant d'am renouveler la vitalité du corps.

TEXT.English: Use the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Apothecary[COLOR_REVERT] to heal troops. They are fast moving, but expensive to produce and maintain. The Apothecary starts out with the [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Medic1[COLOR_REVERT] promotion. Additionally, Apothecary require the Apothecary's Shop in the city in which they are built. The Apothecary can be upgraded to an [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Medic[COLOR_REVERT], after discovering Medicine.
TEXT.French: L'[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Apothicaire[COLOR_REVERT] permet de guérir les troupes. Il se déplace rapidement, mais est plutôt coûteux à produire et à entretenir. Il commence avec la promotion Médecine I. En outre, les Apothicaires ont besoin d'une Herboristerie dans la ville dans laquelle ils sont construits. L'Apothicaire peut être amélioré en [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Médecin[COLOR_REVERT], après avoir découvert la Médecine.

TEXT.English: The Healers Hut contains a collection of various herbs and spices that are used to help cure ailments and restore health.
Apothecary Shop

In colonial times, the apothecary was more than simply a druggist. An apothecary often provided medical treatment, prescribed medicine, trained apprentices, performed surgery and served as man-midwives. Records kept by 18th-century Williamsburg's apothecaries show they practiced as doctor and even made house calls to treat patients. Williamsburg apothecaries also sold cooking spices, candles, salad oil, anchovies, toothbrushes, and tobacco, making them true precursors of today's drugstores.
TEXT.Polish: Apteka - placówka handlowa zajmująca się sprzedażą leków i innych produktów medycznych (np. opatrunków, środków higienicznych). Apteki recepturowe zajmują się także przygotowywaniem leków recepturowychzgodnie z przepisaną przez lekarza receptą. W praktyce pacjencikorzystają w aptekach także z konsultacji medycznych w sprawie stosowania poszczególnych leków w przypadku konkretnych dolegliwości, a nawet, w nagłych przypadkach, z najbardziej podstawowej pomocy medycznej, polegającej na udzieleniu pierwszej pomocy i wezwaniu innego wykwalifikowanego personelu (lekarza, felczera, zespołupogotowia ratunkowego itp.).

TEXT.English: [SPACE]The Apothecary shop provides health to your city and heals units a small amount.
TEXT.French: La Boutique de l'Apothicaire procure de la santé à votre ville, et améliore la guérison des unités.

TEXT.English: Herbal Cures
Health Care Units
TEXT.French: Unités de soins

TEXT.English: Doctor
Great Doctor
Great Doctor

Build the [LINK=BUILDING_HEALERHUT]Healer's Hut[\LINK], [LINK=BUILDING_APOTHECARY_SHOP]Apothecary Shop[\LINK], or a [LINK=BUILDING_HOSPITAL]Hospital[\LINK] to add specialist doctors and increase the odds of getting a Great Doctor.
Use the Great Doctor to build the [LINK=BUILDING_UNIVERSAL_HEALTH_CARE]Universal Health Care[\LINK] National Wonder, discover a new technology or add to a city as a super specialist.
Great Bath of Mohenjo-daro
TEXT.French: Le Grand Bain de Mohenjo-daro

TEXT.English: The "great bath" is without doubt the earliest public water tank in the ancient world. The tank itself measures approximately 12 meters north-south and 7 meters wide, with a maximum depth of 2.4 meters. Two wide staircases lead down into the tank from the north and south and small sockets at the edges of the stairs are thought to have held wooden planks or treads. At the foot of the stairs is a small ledge with a brick edging that extends the entire width of the pool. People coming down the stairs could move along this ledge without actually stepping into the pool itself.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB] The floor of the tank is water tight due to finely fitted bricks laid on edge with gypsum plaster and the side walls were constructed in a similar manner. To make the tank even more water tight, a thick layer of bitumen (natural tar) was laid along the sides of the tank and presumably also beneath the floor. Brick colonnades were discovered on the eastern, northern and southern edges. The preserved columns have stepped edges that may have held wooden screens or window frames. Two large doors lead into the complex from the south and other access was from the north and east. A series of rooms are located along the eastern edge of the building and in one room is a well that may have supplied some of the water needed to fill the tank. Rainwater also may have been collected for this purposes, but no inlet drains have been found.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB] The floor of the tank is water tight due to finely fitted bricks laid on edge with gypsum plaster and the side walls were constructed in a similar manner. To make the tank even more water tight, a thick layer of bitumen (natural tar) was laid along the sides of the tank and presumably also beneath the floor. Brick colonnades were discovered on the eastern, northern and southern edges. The preserved columns have stepped edges that may have held wooden screens or window frames. Two large doors lead into the complex from the south and other access was from the north and east. A series of rooms are located along the eastern edge of the building and in one room is a well that may have supplied some of the water needed to fill the tank. Rainwater also may have been collected for this purposes, but no inlet drains have been found.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB] Most scholars agree that this tank would have been used for special religious functions where water was used to purify and renew the well being of the bathers.

TEXT.Polish: Wielka Łaźnia, położona w obrębie cytadeli miejskiej. Był to kompleks wielu komnat i ośmiu łazienek usytuowanych wokół basenu o wymiarach 12 x 7 x 2,5 metra. Na krótszych bokach basenu znajdowały się schody ułatwiające wejście i wyjście z basenu. Woda napływała z wykładanej cegłami studni. Dno basenu było pochyłe i strome.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Great Bath[COLOR_REVERT] turns your city plot into a source of fresh water and grants +1 population to all newly built cities until the wonder obsoletes. The fresh water bonus does not obsolete.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Grand Bain[COLOR_REVERT] transforme votre ville en source d'eau douce, et garanti à toutes les nouvelles Villes +1 de population jusqu'à ce qu'il soit obsolète. La source d'eau douce n'est jamais obsolète.

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET][COLOR_YELLOW]HELP: [COLOR_REVERT]Creates a Source of Fresh Water. New Cities Built with +1 Population. Fresh Water Bonus does not Obsolete[COLOR_REVERT]
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Créé une source d'eau douce[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Les Nouvelles Villes construites ont +1 Population[NEWLINE][COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]Le Bonus d'eau douce n'est jamais obsolète[COLOR_REVERT]

TEXT.English: Hippocratic Oath
TEXT.French: Serment d'Hippocrate

TEXT.English: The Hippocratic Oath is an oath traditionally taken by physicians pertaining to the ethical practice of medicine. It is widely believed that the oath was written by Hippocrates, the father of western medicine, in the 4th century BC.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hippokrates was an ancient Greek physician of the Age of Pericles, and was considered one of the most outstanding figures in the history of medicine. He is referred to as the "father of medicine".
TEXT.French: The Hippocratic Oath is an oath traditionally taken by physicians pertaining to the ethical practice of medicine. It is widely believed that the oath was written by Hippocrates, the father of western medicine, in the 4th century BC.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hippokrates was an ancient Greek physician du Age of Pericles, and was considered one du most outstanding figures in the history of medicine. He is referred to as the "father of medicine".
TEXT.Polish: Przysięga Hipokratesa - składana przez lekarzy w starożytności, zawierała podstawy dzisiejszej etyki lekarskiej. Wbrew powszechnej opinii jej autorem nie był sam Hipokrates, lecz jego uczniowie, należący do kręgupitagorejczyków (stąd między innymi niechęć do leczenia operacyjnego). Zaś samo sformułowanie podstawowych zasad etycznych zawodu lekarza wielu przypisuje Imhotepowi.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hippocratic Oath[COLOR_REVERT] provides a free [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]healer's hut[COLOR_REVERT] in all your cities.
TEXT.French: Le [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Serment d'Hippocrate[COLOR_REVERT] procure une [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]cabane de guérisseur [COLOR_REVERT] dans chacune de vos villes.

TEXT.English: Surgeon
TEXT.French: Chirurgien

TEXT.English: More skilled than a medic, surgeons can heal soldiers in the battlefield better and faster.
TEXT.French: Plus expérimenté que le médecin, les Chirurgiens peuvent soigner plus rapidement les soldats sur le champ de bataille.

TEXT.English: In medicine, a surgeon is a specialist in surgery. Surgery is a broad category of invasive medical treatment that involves the cutting of a body, whether that of a human or a other animal, for a specific reason such as the removal of diseased tissue or to repair a tear or breakage. Surgeons may be physicians, podiatrists, dentists, or veterinarians. Surgeons usually train for longer than other medical specialists.
Hospital Ship
TEXT.French: Navire Hôpital

TEXT.English: A hospital ship is a ship designated for primary function as a floating medical treatment facility or hospital. Most are operated by the military forces (mostly navies) of various countries, as they are intended to be used in or near war zones. Although attacking a hospital ship is a war crime, belligerent navies have the right to board such ships for inspections.
[COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Hospital Ship[COLOR_REVERT] is medical navy unit which heal every unit in the same tile.
TEXT.German: Hospital Ships are used to heal units. Graphics by Aungi and Nsftpoeopas.
TEXT.Italian: Hospital Ships are used to heal units. Graphics by Aungi and Nsftpoeopas.
TEXT.Spanish: Hospital Ships are used to heal units. Graphics by Aungi and Nsftpoeopas.

TEXT.French: Navire Hôpital II

Ambulance (WWII)
Ambulances are used to heal units. Graphics by Aungi and Nuvoloblu.

TEXT.English: Immigrant

City must have a population of at least 10 and will loose 2 population points to train 1 immigrant. The Immigrant will add 1 population point when joined to a city having a population of less than 7. The maintenance cost of 2 gold per turn ends when the immigrant joins a city.
TEXT.French: La Ville doit avoir une population d'au moins 2, et perdra 2 de population pour entrainer un immigrant. L'Immigrant ajoute 1 de population à une ville de population inférieure à 7. Le cout d'entretien de 2 or par tour s'applique jusqu'à ce que l'immigrant a rejoint une ville.

TEXT.English: Build immigrants in cities that are suffering from unrest due to over population. Use the Immigrant to increase the population and the productive capacity of a new city.
[ICON_BULLET][COLOR_YELLOW]HELP: [COLOR_REVERT]Adds 1 population point when joined to a city.[NEWLINE]Decreases the population in the city where it is built by 2
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Ajoute 1 de population lorsqu'il rejoint une ville.

TEXT.English: %s1_city welcomes the new immigrants with open arms.
TEXT.French: %s1_city accueille les nouveaux immigrants à bras ouverts.

TEXT.English: Join City
TEXT.French: Rejoindre la Ville

TEXT.English: The Ishtar Gate
TEXT.French: La Porte d'Ishtar

TEXT.English: The Ishtar Gate was the eighth gate to the inner city of Babylon. It was constructed in about 575 BC by order of King Nebuchadnezzar II on the north side of the city. Dedicated to the Assyrian goddess Ishtar, the Gate was constructed of blue glazed tiles with alternating rows of bas-relief sirrush (dragons) and aurochs. The roof and doors of the gate were of cedar, according to the dedication plaque. Through the gate ran the Processional Way which was lined with walls covered in lions on glazed bricks (about 120 of them). Statues of the gods were paraded through the gate and down the Processional Way each year during the New Year's celebration. It was originally considered one of the Seven Wonders of the world until, in the 6th century AD, it was replaced with the Lighthouse of Alexandria.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]A reconstruction of the Ishtar Gate and Processional Way was built at the Pergamon Museum in Berlin out of material excavated by Robert Koldewey and finished in the 1930s. It includes the inscription plaque. It stands 47 feet high and 100 feet wide (14 meters by 30 meters). The excavation ran from 1902-1914 and during that time 45 ft of the foundation of the gate was uncovered. Parts of the gate and lions from the Processional Way are in various other museums around the world. A reproduction of the gate was built in Iraq as the entrance to a museum that was never completed. Damage to the gate has supposedly occurred since the Iraq war.
TEXT.French: La porte d'Ishtar est une des huit portes de la cité intérieure de Babylone, elle fut construite au nord de la cité aux alentours de -575 (empire néobabylonien) sur ordre du roi Nabuchodonosor II. Cette porte est dédiée à la déesse éponyme Ishtar. La porte d'Ishtar est l'aboutissement de la voie processionnelle au nord de Babylone. Elle est le symbole même de Babylone. Son nom cultuel est "Ishtar Sakipat Tebisha", ou "Ishtar est victorieuse de ses ennemis". La porte est construite selon le principe de la double porte, c'est-à-dire qu'il y a un mur extérieur et un mur intérieur. La première porte (intérieure) fait 28m de large, 11m de long et est flanquée de deux tours de part et d'autre du passage. La seconde porte (extérieure) est la plus grande. Elle est encastrée dans le rempart intérieur, et est flanquée de deux tours de 9,50m de haut. Entre les deux tours se trouve une cour ouverte. Il y a eu différentes phases de constructions pour la porte d'Ishtar, qui ont à chaque fois modifié son décor: La première phase est caractérisée par un décor émaillé, et la dernière par des bas-reliefs en brique émaillée et colorée. Sur les murs des portes, on trouve des rangées de taureau et de dragons. Le taureau symbolise le dieu Adad (dieu de l'orage). Le dragon est une créature hybride: une queue et un corps de serpent, les pattes arrières en serres d'aigle. La tête du dragon (Mushkhushu) est une représentation du dieu Marduk (et le dragon lui-même est un attribut du dieu Marduk). On note que le lion d'Ishtar n'est pas présent dans les représentations. Sur la porte on peut également noter la présence d'une inscription de Nabuchodonosor II signifiant les détails de la construction, comme sur la voie processionnelle.
TEXT.German: Das Ischtar-Tor - eines der Stadttore von Babylon - sowie die Prozessionsstrasse wurde von Nebukadnezar II. (605-562 v. Chr.) errichtet. Babylon war die Hauptstadt Babyloniens und lag am Euphrat im heutigen Zentral-Irak. Das Ischtar-Tor befindet sich heute im Vorderasiatischen Museum, das im Pergamonmuseum in Berlin untergebracht ist, und ist dort seit 1930 zugänglich. Das Ischtar-Tor befand sich in Babylon am Ende einer von Mauern umgebenen Prozessionsstrasse, die ursprünglich zwischen 20 und 24 Meter breit war und eine Länge von etwa 250 Metern hatte. Diese Prozessionsstrasse wurde von den Babyloniern alljährlich für das Neujahrsfest im Frühling benutzt. Die Mauern, die mit hauptsächlich blau glasierten Ziegeln verkleidet war, war mit Tierdarstellungen verziert, wie sie sich auch am Ischtar-Tor selbst befanden. Das Tor bewachte den Zugang zu einer 90 m hohen Zikkurat, die von einem Marduk-Schrein gekrönt war. Das Ischtar-Tor und die Prozessionsstrasse wurden im Pergamonmuseum unter Verwendung der glasierten Originalziegel rekonstruiert. Die Wände des Tors sind ausgeschmückt mit Darstellungen von Löwen, Stieren und Drachen, die Symbole für die Hauptgottheiten Babylons sind. Die dargestellten Löwen sind Symbole der Göttin Ischtar, Herrin des Himmels, Liebesgöttin und Beschützerin der Armee. Die schlangenähnliche Drachen stellen Muschku (auch Bel genannt), den Gott der Stadt und der Fruchtbarkeit dar, der ewiges Leben schenkte. Die wilden Stiere symbolisierten den Wettergott Adad. "Für Gott Muschku und Nabu befestigte ich das Innere der Strasse und darüber legte ich eine mächtige Anfüllung aus glänzendem Staub. Möget ihr Götter fröhlich wandeln auf diesem Weg", steht auf den ca. 20000 Ziegeln.
TEXT.Italian: La Porta di Ishtar era l'ottavo cancello nel centro urbano di Babilonia; venne costruita intorno al 575 a.C. per ordine del re Nebuchadrezzar II sul lato nord della città. Dedicato alla dea Ishtar, il cancello venne costruito con mattonelle lustrate blu con file alternate di bassorilievi di draghi e tori. Il tetto e le porte del cancello erano di cedro, secondo la piastra di dedica. Attraverso il cancello passava la Via Processionale, delimitata da pareti ornate con circa 120 leoni. Le statue degli dei venivano portate in processione attraverso il cancello e lungo la Via Processionale ogni anno durante la celebrazione del nuovo anno. Una ricostruzione del cancello di Ishtar e della Vua Processionale è stata realizzata al Museo di Pergamo a Berlino, grazie a materiale scavato nelle vicinanze da Robert Koldewey e rifinito negli anni '30, tra cui la piastra dell'iscrizione. Era alta circa 47 piedi e larga 32 piedi. Lo scavo durò dal 1902 al 1914 e durante quel tempo vennero rimossi 45 piedi di terreno fino alle fondamenta del cancello. Le parti del cancello e dei leoni della Via Processionale sono divise in vari musei intorno al mondo: soltanto due musei hanno acquistato i draghi mentre i leoni sono andato a parecchi musei. Ad esempio il museo di archeologia di Costantinopoli ha i leoni, i draghi e i tori; l'Istituto delle arti di Detroit possiede un drago; il Louvre, il Museo metropolitano di arte a New York, l'Istituto orientale di Chicago, la Scuola del Rhode Island di disegno e il Museo delle arti di Boston hanno ciascuno dei leoni. Una riproduzione del cancello è stata realizzata in Irak come entrata ad un museo, che però non è mai stato completato.
TEXT.Spanish: La Puerta de Istar (o de Ishtar) era originalmente una de las 8 puertas monumentales (14 metros de altura por 10 de ancho) de la muralla interior de Babilonia, a través de la cual se accedía al templo de Bel, donde se celebraban las fiestas propias del año nuevo. El nombre de Istar lo recibe de la diosa del mismo nombre a la cual estaba consagrada. Fue construida en el año 575 adC por Nabucodonosor II en el lado norte de la ciudad. Se compone de numerosos ladrillos de adobe, la mayoría pintados de color azul (lo que la hacía contrastar fuertemente con todos los edificios de su alrededor), mientras que otros son dorados o rojizos. éstos últimos se disponen dibujando la silueta de dragones, toros, leones y seres mitológicos. La parte inferior y el arco de la puerta están decoradas por filas de grandes flores semejantes a margaritas. La Puerta de Istar contaba originalmente con dos esfinges dentro del arco de la puerta, que se han perdido hoy en día. Los restos de la puerta original fueron descubiertos en Babilonia durante las campañas arqueológicas alemanas de 1902 a 1914. La mayoría se trasladó a Alemania, donde se reconstruyó la puerta en el Museo Pergamon de Berlín, en 1930, que sigue actualmente en exposición. Algunos de los relieves originales de leones, dragones y toros se encuentran actualmente en el Museo Arqueológico de Estambul, el Instituto de Artes de Detroit, el Museo Metropolitano de Arte de Nueva York, el Instituto Oriental de Chicago, el Museo de la Escuela de Diseño de Rhode Island y el Museo de Bellas Artes de Boston.
TEXT.Polish: Brama Isztar - brama w Babilonie, wzniesiona za panowania królaNabuchodonozora II i poświęcona była bogini Isztar. Była ona północną bramą miasta, otwierającą tzw. drogę procesyjną, która ciągnęła się aż doE-sagili - świątyni boga Marduka. Obiekt tworzyły w zasadzie dwie bramy połączone przejściem, czyli był to tzw. obiekt bramy, składający się z czterech wież na planie kwadratu, zwieńczonych krenelażem, który zresztą był również na murach łączących wieże. Taka konstrukcja miała swoje konkretne, obronne cele i wynikała m.in. z techniki obrony przejścia umieszczonego w dwóch rzędach murów obronnych, w których odrębne bramy połączono dla skuteczniejszej obrony przed napastnikami. Poza tym pozwalało to lepiej kontrolować przybyszów przechodzących przez bramę.

TEXT.English: Temple of Ah Cacao
TEXT.French: Temple de Ah Cacao

TEXT.English: Tikal (or Tik'al, according to the more current orthography) is the largest of the ancient ruined cities of the Mayan civilization. It is located in the El Petén department of Guatemala. Now part of Guatemala's Tikal National Park, it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a popular tourist spot. The closest large towns are Flores and Santa Elena, approximately 64 kilometres (40 mi) by road to the southwest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Tikal Temple I is the designation given to one of the major structures at Tikal, one of the largest cities and archaeological sites of the pre-Columbian Maya civilization in Mesoamerica, located in the Petén Basin region of northern Guatemala. Informally also known as the Temple of the Giant Jaguar or Temple of Ah Cacao, Temple I is a typically Petén-styled limestone stepped pyramid structure which is dated to approximately 730 CE.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The structure is associated with Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, a Classic-era ruler of the polity based at Tikal, who ruled from 682-784. The tomb of this ruler has been located by archaeologists within the structure, although it is presently unclear whether it was built for this specific purpose, or this use was a later adaptation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Temple I reaches a height of approximately 44 m (144.4 ft) over a series of nine steep levels, from a base measuring only 30 by 34 m (98.4 by 111.5 ft). The nine levels may be a reference to the nine "Lords of the Night" in Maya mythology and Initial Series inscriptions. The main chamber of the temple depicts Kukulcan, a feathered serpent god.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Situated at the heart of a World Heritage Site, the temple is surmounted by a typical roofcomb, a distinctive Maya architectural feature.
TEXT.French: Tikal (or Tik'al, according to the more current orthography) is the largest du ancient ruined cities du Mayan civilization. It is located in the El Petén department of Guatemala. Now part of Guatemala's Tikal National Park, it is a UNESCO World Heritage Site et un popular tourist spot. The closest large towns are Flores and Santa Elena, approximately 64 kilometres (40 mi) by road to the southwest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Tikal Temple I is the designation given to one du major structures at Tikal, one du largest cities and archaeological sites du pre-Columbian Maya civilization in Mesoamerica, located in the Petén Basin region of northern Guatemala. Informally also known as the Temple du Giant Jaguar or Temple of Ah Cacao, Temple I is a typically Petén-styled limestone stepped pyramid structure which is dated to approximately 730 CE.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The structure is associated with Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, a Classic-era ruler du polity based at Tikal, who ruled from 682-784. The tomb of this ruler has been located by archaeologists within the structure, although it is presently unclear whether it was built for this specific purpose, or this use was a later adaptation.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Temple I reaches a height of approximately 44 m (144.4 ft) over a series of nine steep levels, from a base measuring only 30 by 34 m (98.4 by 111.5 ft). The nine levels may be a reference to the nine "Lords du Night" in Maya mythology and Initial Series inscriptions. The main chamber du temple depicts Kukulcan, a feathered serpent god.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Situated at the heart of a World Heritage Site, the temple is surmounted by a typical roofcomb, a distinctive Maya architectural feature.
TEXT.Italian: Tikal (o Tik'al, a seconda dell'ortografia più comune) è la più grande rovina della civiltà Maya. Si trova nel dipartimento di El Petén, in Guatemala. Ora parte del Guatemala's Tikal National Park, è un sito dell'UNESCO dichiarato patrimonio dell'umanità e una grande attrazione turistica. e città più vicine sono Flores e Santa Elena, circa 64 km a sud-ovest.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Tikal Temple I è la designazione inglese di una delle strutture più grandi di Tikal, una delle città più grandi costruite dalla civiltà pre-colombiana dei maya nell'America Centrale, situata nella regione del Bacino di Petén nel nord del Guatemala. Conosciuto anche come tempio del Grande Giaguaro o Tempio di Ah Cacao, Temple I ha uno stile tipico della regione, con una struttura a piramide in pietra risalente circa al 730 d.C..[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]La struttura è associata a Jasaw Chan K'awiil I, un governatore dell'era classica che era stanziato a Tikal, che goernò dal 682 al 784. La tomba di questo governatore è stata localizzata dagli archeologi all'interno della struttura, anche se al momento non è chiaro de la piramide fu costruita per questo scopo preciso o se questo uso sia stato un adattamento successivo.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Temple I ha un'altezza di circa 44 m su una serie di nove livelli, da una base di misure 30x34 m. I nove livelli potrebbero essere un riferimento ai nove "Signori della notte" della mitologia Maya mythology e alle iscrizioni delle Serie iniziali. La camera principale del tempio rappresenta Kukulcan, il dio-serpente piumato.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Al centro del sito UNESCO, il tempio è sormontato da un elemento architettonico tipico della cultura maya.

TEXT.English: Library of Nineveh
TEXT.French: La Bibliothèque de Ninive

TEXT.English: The Royal Library of Ashurbanipal was discovered in a palace in ancient Nineveh, capital of Assyria, in northern Mesopotamia (modern day Iraq). The of King Ashurbanipal (668 - 627 BC) was the last great king of the Neo-Assyrian Empire and the palace is the second most important library discovery of the ancient world. The library is a collection of thousands of clay tablets and fragments containing texts of all kinds from the 7th century BC. Among its holdings was the famous Epic of Gilgamesh. Due to the sloppy handling of the original material much of the library is irreparably jumbled, making it impossible for scholars to discern and reconstruct many of the original texts, although some have survived intact.
TEXT.French: La Bibliothèque royale d'Assurbanipal a été découverte dans un palais de l'ancienne Ninive, capitale de l'Assyrie, dans le nord de la Mésopotamie (l'Irak de jour). Le roi Assurbanipal (668 à 627 avant JC) fut le dernier grand roi de l'empire néo-assyrien et le palais constitue la deuxième découverte libraire la plus importante du monde antique. La bibliothèque est une collection de milliers de tablettes d'argile et de fragments contenant des textes de toutes sortes à partir de la 7ème siècle avant JC. Parmi ses artefacts se trouvait la célèbre épopée de Gilgamesh. En raison de la manipulation bâclée du matériau d'origine une grande partie de la bibliothèque est irrémédiablement brouillée, ce qui les chercheurs incapables de discerner et de reconstruire la plupart des textes originaux, bien que certains aient survécu presque en intégralité.
TEXT.Polish: Biblioteka Aszurbanipala w Niniwie - założona przez asyryjskiegokróla Aszurbanipala w połowie VII w. p.n.e. Została odkryta w dwóch fazach w czasie prac wykopaliskowych prowadzonych od 1849 roku przez Austena H. Layarda w Niniwie na wzgórzu Kujundżyk, które kryło w sobie pozostałości pałaców: Sennacheryba i Aszurbanipala. Kolekcja zawiera łącznie ok. 20 000 glinianych tabliczek z obydwu pałaców. W wyniku zaniedbania pracowników Muzeum Brytyjskiegotabliczki odkryte w pałacu Sanheriba uległy wymieszaniu ze zbiorem odkrytym w 1852 w pałacu Aszurbanipala przez Hormuzda Rassama, dlatego nie można przyporządkować poszczególnych tabliczek do określonej biblioteki pałacowej któregoś z obu władców.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]The Library of Nineveh[COLOR_REVERT] is a World Wonder that provides both a FREE [LINK=BUILDING_TABLET_MAKER]Tablet Maker[\LINK] and +5 percent research in every city. Additionally, the city, in which it is produced receives a 15% increase in research and is more likely to produce a Great Scientist.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]La Bibliothèque de Ninive[COLOR_REVERT]est une merveille du monde qui offre à la fois un [LINK = BUILDING_TABLET_MAKER] Fabricant de Tablettes [\ LINK] GRATUIT et +5 pourcent de recherche dans chaque ville. En outre, la ville dans laquelle elle est construite reçoit une augmentation de 15% dans la recherche et est plus susceptible de produire un Savant Illustre.

TEXT.English: Topkapi Palace
TEXT.French: Le Palais Topkapi

TEXT.English: The Topkapi Palace is a palace in Istanbul, Turkey, which was the official and primary residence in the city of the Ottoman Sultans, from 1465 to 1853. The palace was a setting for state occasions and royal entertainments and is a major tourist attraction today. The name directly translates as "Cannongate Palace", from the palace being named after a nearby, now lost gate.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Initial construction started in 1459, ordered by Sultan Mehmed II, the conqueror of Byzantine Constantinople. The palace is a complex made up of four main courtyards and many smaller buildings. At the height of its existence as a royal residence, the palace was home to as many as 4,000 people, formerly covering a larger area with a long shoreline. The complex has been expanded over the centuries, with many renovations such as after the 1509 earthquake and 1665 fire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Topkapi Palace gradually lost its importance at the end of the 17th century, as the Sultans preferred to spend more time in their new palaces along the Bosporus. In 1853, Sultan Abdül Mecid I decided to move the court to the newly built Dolmabahçe Palace, the first European-style palace in the city. Some functions, such as the imperial treasury, the library, mosque and mint, were retained though.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]After the end of the Ottoman Empire in 1921, Topkapi Palace was transformed by government decree on April 3, 1924 into a museum of the imperial era. The Topkapi Palace Museum is under the administration of the Ministry of Culture and Tourism. The palace complex has hundreds of rooms and chambers, but only the most important are accessible to the public today. The complex is guarded by officials of the ministry as well as armed guards of the Turkish military. The palace is full of examples of Ottoman architecture and also contains large collections of porcelain, robes, weapons, shields, armor, Ottoman miniatures, Islamic calligraphic manuscripts and murals, as well as a display of Ottoman treasure and jewelry.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Topkapi Palace is among those monuments belonging to the "Historic Areas of Istanbul", which became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985, and is described in Criterion iv as "the best example[s] of ensembles of palaces [...] of the Ottoman period."
TEXT.French: The Topkapi Palace is a palace in Istanbul, Turkey, which was the official and primary residence in the city du Ottoman Sultans, from 1465 to 1853. The palace was a setting for state occasions and royal entertainments and is a major tourist attraction today. The name directly translates as "Cannongate Palace", from the palace being named after a nearby, now lost gate.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Initial construction started in 1459, ordered by Sultan Mehmed II, the conqueror of Byzantine Constantinople. The palace is a complex made up of four main courtyards and many smaller buildings. At the height of its existence as a royal residence, the palace was home to as many as 4,000 people, formerly covering a larger area with a long shoreline. The complex has been expanded over the centuries, with many renovations such as after the 1509 earthquake and 1665 fire.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Topkapi Palace gradually lost its importance at the end du 17th century, as the Sultans preferred to spend more time in their new palaces along the Bosporus. In 1853, Sultan Abdül Mecid I decided to move the court to the newly built Dolmabahçe Palace, the first European-style palace in the city. Some functions, such as the imperial treasury, the library, mosque and mint, were retained though.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]After the end du Ottoman Empire in 1921, Topkapi Palace was transformed by government decree on Avril 3, 1924 into a museum du imperial era. The Topkapi Palace Museum is under the administration du Ministry of Culture and Tourism. The palace complex has hundreds of rooms and chambers, but only the most important are accessible to the public today. The complex is guarded by officials du ministry as well as armed guards du Turc military. The palace is full of examples of Ottoman architecture and also contains large collections of porcelain, robes, weapons, shields, armor, Ottoman miniatures, Islamic calligraphic manuscripts and murals, as well as a display of Ottoman treasure and jewelry.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Topkapi Palace is among those monuments belonging to the "Historic Areas of Istanbul", which became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985, and is described in Criterion iv as "the best example[s] of ensembles of palaces [...] du Ottoman period."
TEXT.Italian: Il Palazzo Topkapi è un palazzo di Istanbul, in Turchia, che fu usato dei sultani Ottomani come residenza dal 1465 al 1853; il palazzo era il luogo designato per gli incontri di stato e l'intrattenimento della famiglia reale, mentre al giorno d'oggi è una grande attrazione turistica. Il nome viene tradotto con "Palazzo della Porta del Cannone", basandosi su una porta vicina ora distrutta.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]La costruzione iniziò nel 1459 su ordine del Sultano Mehmed II, il conquistatore di Costantinopoli. Il palazzo è un complesso formato da 4 cortili principlai e molti edifici più piccoli; nel suo periodo di massimo splendore il palazzo ospitava più di 4,000 persone, occupando un'area sempre più grande lungo la costa; il complesso si è quindi ingrandito nel corso dei secoli, con molti restauri come il territorio del 1509 e l'incendio del 1665.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Il Palazzo Topkapi perse gradualmente importanza alla fine del XVII secolo, quando i Sultani iniziarono a trascorrere più tempo nei loro nuovi palazzi lungo il Bosforo. Nel 1853 il Sultano Abdül Mecid I decise di spostare la propria corte nel Palazzo Dolmabahçe, il primo palazzo in stile europeo della città. Alcune funzioni rimasero però al Palazzo Topkapi, come il tesoro, la biblioteca, la moschea e la zecca.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Dopo la fine dell'Impero Ottomano nel 1921 il palazzo Topkapi fu trasformato dal decreto governativo del 3 aprile 1924 nel museo dell'Era imperiale. Il Museo del Palazzo Topkapi è sotto la giurisdizione del Ministero della cultura e del turismo; il complesso ha centinaia di stanze, ma solo le più importanti possono essere visitate. Il complesso è sorvegliato da ufficiali del ministero e da guardie armate dell'esercito turco. Il palazzo è pieno di esampi di architettura e contiene grandi collezioni di porcellane, abiti, armi, scudi, armature, miniature Ottomane, manoscritti di calligrafia islamica e murali, oltre a mostre del tesoro e dei gioielli ottomani.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Il Palazzo Topkapi è uno dei monumenti appartenenti alla "Area storica di Istanbul", che fu dichiarato dall'UNESCO Patrimonio dell'umanità nel 1985, descritto da Criterion IV come "the best example[s] of ensembles of palaces [...] of the Ottoman period."
TEXT.Polish: Topkapi Sarayi - pałac w centrum Stambułu, który był rezydencją sułtanówprzez ponad 380 lat, od 1453 roku. Budowę rozpoczęto za panowania sułtanaMehmeda II Zdobywcy w 1453 roku, zaraz po zdobyciu Konstantynopola, a zakończono w 1465 roku. Ostatnim używającym pałacu sułtanem byłMahmud II (do 1839 roku). Sułtan Abdulmecid I przeniósł siedzibę władców do pałacu DolmabahCe.
